docs.snippet: From all outward signs, it would seem as if George Clooney has life by the tail. Riding not one but two movies into the Oscars, he would seem likely to walk away with one of those little guys in his hands, but not according to one handicapper. "I ...
docs.lead_paragraph: From all outward signs, it would seem as if George Clooney has life by the tail. Riding not one but two movies into the Oscars, he would seem likely to walk away with one of those little guys in his hands, but not according to one handicapper. "I don't think we're going to win any," Mr. Clooney told reporters Friday at Berlin's annual film festival. "There's been a lot of 'Brokeback Mountain' stuff." The Bagger knows that Mr. Clooney is up against some sincere competition both in terms of acting and directing, but he also knows that the Academy would dearly love to get the one superstar of this year's Oscar roster up to the microphone. It will be a long night without Mr. Clooney's trademark of sincerity and hijinks.
docs.abstract: From all outward signs, it would seem as if George Clooney has life by the tail. Riding not one but two movies into the Oscars, he would seem likely to walk away with one of those little guys in his hands, but not according to one handicapper. "I don't think we're going to win any," [...]

docs.snippet: Nominees for a Grammy Award, not to mention an Oscar or a Tony, inevitably see a boost in sales, but the exact connection between the two can be unpredictable. Paul McCartney's album ''Chaos and Creation in the Backyard'' benefited most after the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nominees for a Grammy Award, not to mention an Oscar or a Tony, inevitably see a boost in sales, but the exact connection between the two can be unpredictable. Paul McCartney's album ''Chaos and Creation in the Backyard'' benefited most after the Grammy nominations on Dec. 8. Sales of the eventual winner in the best album category, ''How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb,'' by U2 (above), changed only slightly after it was nominated.

docs.snippet: Provenance of 'Paradise Now' Is Questioned Before Oscars       Israeli diplomats and Jewish groups are lobbying organizers of the Academy Awards not to present a nominated film about Palestinian suicide bombers as coming from Palestine, an Israeli...
docs.lead_paragraph: Provenance of 'Paradise Now' Is Questioned Before Oscars Israeli diplomats and Jewish groups are lobbying organizers of the Academy Awards not to present a nominated film about Palestinian suicide bombers as coming from Palestine, an Israeli newspaper reported yesterday. The movie, ''Paradise Now,'' a drama about two young men from the occupied West Bank recruited to blow themselves up in Tel Aviv, is up for the Oscar for best foreign film. It had a Palestinian crew, an Israeli producer and European financing, but it is listed by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences' Web site as coming from Palestine. The film's director, Hany Abu-Assad, above, is an Israeli-born Palestinian. Yedioth Ahronoth, the Israeli newspaper, said the Israeli consulate in Los Angeles and Jewish groups were urging the academy to reconsider the national label ''given that the Palestinian Authority has yet to be declared a state,'' Reuters reported. According to the newspaper, organizers of the ceremony agreed to provide an unspecified alternative provenance for the film. The academy could not immediately be reached for confirmation yesterday. The Foreign Ministry of Israel declined to comment. 'Fahrenheit 451' Due Off Broadway Ray Bradbury's stage version of his 1953 science-fiction classic ''Fahrenheit 451'' will make its New York premiere at 59E59 Theaters on East 59th Street in Manhattan next month in a production by Godlight Theater Company. This Off Broadway version will be directed by Joe Tantalo and begin previews on March 16. Opening night is March 21, and the limited engagement is to end April 23. Godlight had a hit at 59E59 last year with an adaptation of Anthony Burgess's ''Clockwork Orange.'' The next offering at the Pearl Theater Company will be Shakespeare's ''Measure for Measure.'' Directed by Beatrice Terry with a cast including Sean McNall and Rachel Botchan, the Off Broadway production will begin previews at Theater 80 on St. Mark's Place in the East Village on Feb. 23 and open on March 5. Footnote The 16th annual Tibet House benefit concert at Carnegie Hall will be on March 1 at 7:30 p.m. with a lineup that is to include Philip Glass, Laurie Anderson and Sufjan Stevens.
docs.abstract: Israeli diplomats and Jewish groups lobby organizers of Academy Awards not to label Paradise Now, movie about Palestinian suicide bombers that is nominated for best foreign film award, as coming from Palestine; photo (S)

docs.snippet: Need something to fiddle with while posing for the paparazzi? Seen in demure profusion on many a famous wrist lately is the seven-bangle semanario bracelet. Spanish in origin, the bracelets are a favorite of celebrities like Angelina Jolie, left, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Need something to fiddle with while posing for the paparazzi? Seen in demure profusion on many a famous wrist lately is the seven-bangle semanario bracelet. Spanish in origin, the bracelets are a favorite of celebrities like Angelina Jolie, left, and Lindsay Lohan; each bangle is thought to represent a day of the week and to give the wearer good luck. Ms. Jolie's diamond-studded circles, in 24-karat hammered gold by Gurhan, are $2,700 each at www.neimanmarcus.com. A set in 18-karat gold, above right, is $5,825 at Me&Ro in New York, (917) 237-9215; Oscar & Nancy's gold, copper and silver-plated ovals, above left, are $70 at Wink in New York, (212) 334-3646. If just one lucky bracelet is more your style, Mexgrocer.com's, top, gives the most jingle for your buck, stringing 18 medals, mostly saints, on a single strand, for a mere $25. SUSAN GUERRERO
docs.abstract: Locations to purchase latest trend in bracelets and bangles noted; photos (M)

docs.snippet: SAHARA (1943)  Thursday at 8 p.m. on TCM  Zoltan Korda's drama about World War II Allied soldiers alone in a tank in the desert follows all the rules for old-fashioned war movies. The hero has a strong name: Sgt. Joe Gunn (Humphrey Bogart). At lea...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAHARA (1943) Thursday at 8 p.m. on TCM Zoltan Korda's drama about World War II Allied soldiers alone in a tank in the desert follows all the rules for old-fashioned war movies. The hero has a strong name: Sgt. Joe Gunn (Humphrey Bogart). At least one American soldier is nicknamed for his home state or city (Bruce Bennett as Waco Hoyt). The man from France is called Frenchie (Louis Mercier). A European character is played by an American actor of a completely different ethnic background (J. Carrol Naish as Giuseppe). And there's real, heartfelt drama. This film manages to wring suspense out of the ''three swallows'' rule that applies to their very limited water supply. COP LAND (1997) Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 11 It's best not to think of this dark police drama as a Sylvester Stallone movie. Mr. Stallone (left) can be hard to buy as a wimpy small-town New Jersey sheriff, cowed by the New York policemen who live in his town and take police corruption to its worst possible conclusion. It's the supporting cast who make it work: Robert De Niro, Harvey Keitel, Ray Liotta and a host of others, including John Spencer, the ''West Wing'' star who died last December, as one of the truly bad guys. James Mangold, who did ''Walk the Line,'' wrote and directed. CYRANO DE BERGERAC (1990) Sunday at 8 p.m., Wednesday at 8:25 a.m., and Saturday at 7:30 a.m. and 5:35 p.m. on Flix There must have been a thousand Cyranos since Edmond Rostand immortalized him in 1897, but few have captured the character's soul as Gérard Depardieu (right) does in Jean-Paul Rappeneau's film version. The story remains the same: Cyrano worships Roxane but fears her rejection because he isn't the handsomest guy in the world. In fact, he has a remarkably large nose. When Christian, a fellow guardsman, wants to woo Roxane, Cyrano helps by writing (and speaking, while unseen) beautiful words of love. Anne Brochet is Mr. Depardieu's Roxane. The devastatingly handsome Vincent Perez plays Christian. DICK (1999) Saturday at 7 p.m. on Comedy Central In Andrew Fleming's daffy satire, the real heroes of the Watergate investigation weren't the Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein. They were two teenage dog walkers working for President Nixon (Dan Hedaya) at the time. The teenagers are played by Michelle Williams, now an Oscar nominee for ''Brokeback Mountain,'' and Kirsten Dunst (far left, with Ms. Williams). The supporting cast includes Dave Foley, Teri Garr, Will Ferrell (as Mr. Woodward) and Harry Shearer (as G. Gordon Liddy).

docs.snippet: Charles Henry joined the New York Police Department in 1951, and in his 31-year career commanded some of the city's toughest precincts during troubled times....
docs.lead_paragraph: Charles O. Henry, a former chief of the New York City housing police who commanded some of the city's toughest precincts in troubled times, died at his home in Las Vegas on Feb. 1. He was 78. He died after a brief illness, his family said.
docs.abstract: Former New York City housing police chief Charles O Henry dies at age 78 (M)

docs.snippet: Bowing to e-mail and other technologies, Western Union dispatched its last telegram two weeks ago. Here is a sample of famous, infamous and apocryphal dispatches....
docs.lead_paragraph: MRS. Sandoval,'' Homer Macauley said, ''your son is dead. Maybe it's a mistake. Maybe it wasn't your son. Maybe it was somebody else. The telegram says it was Juan Domingo. But maybe the telegram is wrong.'' Beginning in the mid-19th century, the telegram was the most immediate way of distributing news or sending a message. Whether it was one of those dreaded ''regret to inform you'' notices from the War Department that William Saroyan's Homer delivered in ''The Human Comedy,'' or ''send money'' pleas or birthday congratulations, the arrival by hand of those yellow envelopes always seemed momentous. In that spirit, the evangelist Billy Graham was quoted as saying, ''I am only a Western Union messenger boy, delivering a telegram from God to the door of humanity.''
docs.abstract: Western Union dispatches its final telegram, finally succumbing to e-mail and other modern technologies; sampling of famous, infamous and apocryphal telegrams is offered; photo (M)

headline.kicker: Word for Word | The Rest Is Silence

docs.snippet: OBERWEGER--Tania (nee Zindel). Passed away peacefully on February 10, 2006, at the age of 95. Loving widow of Oscar, beloved mother of Gideon, mother-in-law of Claudia, grandmother of Alexander and Timothy, grandmother-in-law of Caroline and Willo...
docs.lead_paragraph: OBERWEGER--Tania (nee Zindel). Passed away peacefully on February 10, 2006, at the age of 95. Loving widow of Oscar, beloved mother of Gideon, mother-in-law of Claudia, grandmother of Alexander and Timothy, grandmother-in-law of Caroline and Willow, and greatgrandmother of Naomi Grace. Twentieth Century survivor who brought happiness to all she met and knew. Born in 1910, in Rovno, Poland, on the border of Russia, displaced to Palestine in 1938, the only surviving daughter of David and Bathsheba Zindel, and youngest of 10 children. Present at the creation of Israel, immigrated to the United States in 1951. We will always love and miss you. Services to be held on Sunday, February 13, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations to www.mpdfoundation.org.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths   OBERWEGER, TANIA (NEE ZINDEL)
